School of Science, Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology Xi’an 710055 Shaanxi China Graphical abstract T-carbon [110] monolayer with natural macropores exhibits excellent trifunctional electrocatalytic activity after embedding transition metal and nonmetal active centers. The design of efficient and low-cost multifunctional electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is critical for the development of clean energy. Two-dimensional (2D) carbon-based nano-materials are becoming more and more popular in heterogeneous catalysis due to their cost-effective and multi-scale tunability as single-atom catalysis (SACs) substrates. In this paper, by using first-principles calculation, we designed and demonstrated a novel macropore T-carbon [110] (TC) monolayer as 2D electrocatalyst substrate for HER/OER/ORR, and the synergistic modification of the transition metal and nonmetal atoms (TM-X) were investigated to enhance the multifunctional electrocatalytic performance. We screened out the Co embedded in N-doped TC (Co3@N-TC) from 30 TM@X-TC monolayers as a trifunctional electrocatalysts, which exhibits superior performance for HER/ORR/OER on both thermodynamic and kinetic scales, and with excellent thermal and electrochemical stability. Then, the TC monolayer is naturally macropore with a diameter of 5.36 Å and exhibits excellent adsorption capacity for the intermediates and products of the redox reactions. Moreover, we revealed the origin of the electrocatalytic activity using the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) and the molecular orbitals (MOs). The d orbital of Co3@N-TC is significantly hybridized with the p orbital of the intermediates, so that the lone electrons initially occupied in the antibonding state pair up and occupy the downward bonding state, allowing *OH to be appropriately adsorbed onto the TC monolayer. This work not only demonstrates that the TM@X-TC monolayer is a superior synergistic trifunctional electrocatalyst, but also reveals a macropore monolayer material with potential applications in electrocatalysis. Keywords Carbon-based nano-materials Macropore Single-atom catalyst Multifunctional electrocatalyst First-principles calculation 1 Introduction In clean and sustainable energy technologies, such as water electrolyzers, fuel cells and metal-air batteries, the redox reaction determines the overall energy conversion efficiency [1–4]. Owing to the multistep proton-coupled electron transfer reaction pathways, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) are all limited by the sluggish kinetics and high energy barriers, which lead to the low conversion of electric energy [5–7]. Despite the noble-metal-based electrocatalysts have been utilized for HER (Pt), ORR (Pt), and OER (Ir/RuO x ), but the scarcity and high cost hamper their industrial level applications [8–11]. In addition, the combination of single function catalysts for multifunctional electrocatalysts would consume multiple electrodes to meet different working conditions, makes the device significantly more complex [12,13]. Therefore, developing cost-effective multifunctional electrocatalysts based on 2D carbon-based nano-materials is imperative for future scale-up production, typical examples are the water splitting devices (HER/OER) and the metal-air batteries (OER/ORR) [14,15]. Currently, many approaches have been developed to promote the electrocatalytic activity, including heteroatom doping, heterostructure design, and metal-active site construction. And, with the rapid development of physicochemical synthesis technology, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), single atom catalysts (SACs), high entropy alloys (HEA) and other complex structures have been widely applied in the field of multifunctional electrocatalysts [16–19]. The SACs catalysts have been widely investigated to improve the multifunctional electrocatalytic performance because of low cost, high atom utilization efficiency and adjustable catalytic activity [20,21]. On the basis of SACs, the metal-nonmetal-carbon (M−N−C) structure is introduced to improve the electronic environment, such as the transition metals embedded in pyridine nitrogen ligands on carbon-based catalysts [22–24]. The M−N−C structure optimizes the charge transfer ability in the catalyst and improves the catalytic performance through the complementary and synergistic effects between the center metal atoms, the coordinated atoms, the environmental atoms, and the guest groups [25,26], it is widely concerned in CO2 reduction reactions (CO2RR), N2 reduction reactions (NRR), and bifunctional catalysis such as OER/ORR [27–30]. Graphene as the cornerstone of 2D carbon-based materials, is widely used in the fields of energy storage and catalysis because of large specific surface, plasticity, high conductivity and pores [31–34]. In particular, transition metal embedded in graphene and graphyne have been extensively studied as high-performance multifunctional electrocatalysts [35,36]. So it is necessary to explore the multifunctional catalytic performance of novel carbon allotropes that have been synthesized, such as graphyne, penta-graphene, BPN, C60 and T-carbon [37–42]. Among these novel materials, the T-carbon is the light material with the lowest density among various carbon allotropes, and the 110 crystal face has macropore composed of 12 carbon atoms, and can be synthesized by various methods [42–44]. The T-carbon [110] (TC) monolayer has even been studied in perovskite solar cells, no report has ever been found on the application in electrocatalyst [45–47]. Moreover, the macropore with different diameters from graphdiyne and ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) may have intriguing effects on the redox reaction, such as large pore size N and P doped OMC membrane electrode assembly produced 70% of the maximum power density obtained using Pt/C [48,49]. And the Fe-doped p-BN with pore size of 12 atoms has a working voltage of 0.4 V in ORR [50]. In general, the influence of the mesopores on the multifunctional electrocatalysts cannot be neglected, and there is still a lack of research on how these macropore affect redox reactions. As a kind of macropore material, the TC monolayer is suitable for study. In this study, by using first-principles calculation, we designed and demonstrated a novel macropore T-carbon [110] (TC) monolayer as 2D electrocatalyst substrate for multifunctional electrocatalysts, and explored the electrocatalytic properties of transition metal (TM = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) embedded in nonmetal (X = B, N) doped (TM@X) TC monolayer. Our calculation results showed that the Co embedded in N-doped (Co3@N) TC monolayers exhibits superior performance for HER/OER/ORR on both thermodynamic and kinetic scales, and the macropore in the TC can improve the synergistic catalytic performance. Moreover, we revealed the origin of the electrocatalytic activity using the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) and the molecular orbitals (MOs). Our results provide a strategy for the design of novel synergistic trifunctional electrocatalyst for HER/OER/ORR, and this approach can be applied to other carbon-based nano-materials. 2 Computational method In this study, all the structure optimization were performed using the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) based on density functional theory (DFT) with the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method [51–53]. The electron exchange–correlation interactions were described using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [54]. The Grimme correction (DFT + D3) was used for van der Waals (vdW) interactions between the intermediates and catalysts [55]. A 520 eV energy cut-off was taken for the plane-wave basis set and spin effects were also taken into account. The structure was fully relaxed until the atomic force was less than 0.02 eV Å−1 and the energy convergence standard was set to 10−5 eV. In order to ensure the accuracy and efficiency of the calculation, a Gamma-centered k-point mesh with a Monkhorst-Pack method 5 × 5 × 1 was employed for all considered structures after the convergence test. The surface (basal plane) was modeled by a 2 × 2 supercell. The DFT + U is used to approximate the strong Coulomb force between the transition metal atoms. The calculated U values of Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn were 2.5 [56], 1.8 [57], 2.4 [57], 4.8 [58], 7.5 eV [59], respectively. The monolayers are separated in the z-direction by 18 Å vacuum to prevent interactions between two layers. In the calculation of thermal stability, the Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations at a fluctuant temperature around 300 K with a Nose-Hoover thermostat method was adopted to evaluate the stabilities of the electrocatalysts. The simulation time was set to a time length of 2 ps (time step = 1 fs). The climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method was used to investigate the reaction pathway and energy barrier of HER/ORR/OER [60]. The VASPKIT programmer was applied for the post-processing of VASP calculated data [61]. In addition, the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis was carried out to quantify the strength (ICOHP) of TM–O bond after *OOH, *O, and *OH adsorption using the LOBSTER program [62,63]. In acid electrolytes, the OER process is the reverse direction of ORR process, which can be decomposed into four-electron transfer reaction pathway (1) ∗ + O 2 + H + + e - → ∗ OOH (2) ∗ OOH + H + + e - → ∗ O + H 2 O (3) ∗ O + H + + e - → ∗ OH (4) ∗ OH + H + + e - → ∗ + H 2 O where *, *OOH, *O and *OH denote adsorbed sites, adsorbed intermediates OOH, O, and OH, respectively. In HER process, the H2 generation consists of Volmer mechanism of hydrogen adsorption and Tafel and Heyrovsky mechanism of desorption [64,65] (5) ∗ + H + + e - → ∗ H ( Volmer ) (6) ∗ H + H + + e - → H 2 + ∗ ( Tafel ) (7) 2 ∗ H → H 2 + 2 ∗ ( Heyrovsky ) where *H denotes adsorbed intermediates hydrogen. The Gibbs free energy ΔG i (i = OOH*, O*, OH*, H*) was calculated according to the theoretical hydrogen electrode (CHE) model, which is defined as follows [66,67] (8) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE - T Δ S + Δ G pH + Δ G U where ΔE ZPE is the difference of zero-point energies (ZPEs), T is the temperature (T = 298.15 K) and ΔS is the entropic changes. ΔG pH = k B Tln(10)·pH, ΔG pH is the H+ free energy correction with concentrations, and pH = 0 is employed in this work. ΔG U = − neU is the contribution of applied electrode potential, where n is the number of electrons transferred in each elemental reaction and U is the applied electrode potential. And the η HER is defined as (9) η HER = - Δ G H ∗ e The reaction free energies of OER and ORR are 4.92 and −4.92 eV, respectively. And all four electron transfer steps should be the same (4.92 V/4 = 1.23 V) versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) at zero potential. The reaction rates of the ORR and OER process depended on the rate-limiting, which is determined from the most positive or the most negative reaction free energy, respectively. (10) Δ G 1 = Δ G OOH ∗ - 4.92 eV (11) Δ G 2 = Δ G O ∗ - Δ G OOH ∗ (12) Δ G 3 = Δ G OH ∗ - Δ G O ∗ (13) Δ G 4 = - Δ G OH ∗ Then, based on the above free energy results, the thermodynamic overpotential η of ORR/OER can be obtained using Eqs. (14) and (15) (14) η ORR = max Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 / e + 1.23 V (15) η OER = - min Δ G 1 , - Δ G 2 , - Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 / e - 1.23 V The lower the overpotential, the better the ORR and OER performance of a given electrocatalyst. As a descriptor for evaluating the bifunctional electrocatalyst, overvoltage Δη, which makes ORR and OER overvoltage synchronously decreased, is defined as (16) Δ η = η ORR + η OER An ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst with a smaller Δη value can serve as a reversible oxygen electrode with high performance. And the overvoltage of excellent bifunctional electrocatalyst should be lower than the sum of the overpotential of IrO2 and Pt (η OER + η ORR = 0.56 + 0.47 = 1.03 V), so we choose 1 as the ideal overvoltage value. In this work, the adsorption energy (ΔE) is used to describe the strength of the adsorption capacity of the intermediate and product on the substrate at different concentrations, is defined as (17) Δ E = E TC + n X - E TC + ( n - 1 ) X - E X where E TC+nX and E TC+(n–1)X represent the total energy at different adsorption concentrations, n represents the number of adsorption, X represents the intermediate or product, and E X represents the energy of the intermediate and product. The formation energy (E form) was calculated to verify the stability of the structure, E form is defined as (18) E form = E model - E Vc - m E X - E TM where E model and E Vc are the total energy of the TM embedded TC monolayer and the TC monolayer with one or three carbon atoms missing, respectively. E X and E TM represent the energies of the nonmetals and transition metals, respectively, and m represents the number of nonmetals. The dissolution potential Udiss are effective to evaluate electrochemical stabilities of catalysts with the following formulas [68,69] (19) U diss = U diss 0 ( metal , bulk ) - E form ne U diss 0 (metal, bulk) and n are the standard dissolution potential of bulk metal and the number of electrons involved in the dissolution, respectively. We calculated the exchange current density i 0, which represents the reaction rate of proton transfer from solvent to catalyst surface. Under standard conditions (pH = 0 and T = 300 K), when ΔG H* > 0, i 0 can be defined as [70] (20) i 0 = - e k 0 1 1 + exp ( - Δ G H ∗ / k T ) Conversely, when ΔG H* < 0, i 0 can be defined as (21) i 0 = - e k 0 1 1 + exp ( - Δ G H ∗ / k T ) exp ( - Δ G H ∗ / k T ) where k is the Boltzmann constant and k 0 is the rate constant (k 0 = 200 s−1 site−1). In order to analyze the origin of ORR and OER performance in the following sections, we calculate the band center of the antibonding state through the equation [71] (22) E anti - bonding = ∫ E f + ∞ E × ρ d E + ρ p E d E ∫ E f + ∞ ρ d E + ρ p E d E where ρ d and ρ p are the partial density of state of d-orbital of TM atom and p-orbital of O atom, respectively, and E f is the Fermi level. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures and stabilities of TC The 3D T-carbon can be perceived as a carbon tetrahedron replacing the sp 3 hybridized carbon atoms in diamond, as shown in Fig. S1. For more adsorption sites and larger surface area to promote the catalytic activity, we focus on the [110] crystal plane of the 2D TC monolayer with a macropore consisting of 12 carbon atoms. The unit cell of TC monolayer is composed of 6 carbon atoms, and the lattice constant is a = b = 5.19 Å, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The C−C bond length in the triangle is 1.42 Å, and the C−C bond length between the regular triangles is 1.35 Å. The interior angle of the macropore is 150.2°, and the diameter is 5.36 Å. The density of carbon atoms in TC is 0.22 atom Å−2, which is lower than the density of graphene of 0.33 atom Å−2. Moreover, owning to the C−C carbon bonds within the triangle are connected by sp 3 hybrid σ bonds, and the more stable C=C carbon bonds between the triangles are connected by sp 2 hybrid σ and π bonds. Then, the thermodynamic stability of TC monolayer is described by AIMD simulation with canonical (NVT) ensemble, as shown in Fig. 1(b). The results showed that the energy and temperature oscillate in a small area, and the geometry of the framework of TC monolayer display a slight distortion, indicating the excellent thermodynamic stability of the TC monolayer. As a result, TC monolayer can be used as a substrate for our novel TM@X-TC monolayer materials, and their performance as multifunctional electrocatalyst may be enhanced by modulation. Because heteroatoms can affect the local charge distribution of the material and change the electronic performance of materials, embedded heteroatoms in substrates is one of the most effective ways to improve the catalytic performance. The electron charge density difference analysis of the TM@X-TC monolayer materials are shown in Fig. S2, we can see that strong charge transfer occurs with multiple C atoms around the macropore, due to the active outer electrons of the TM atoms. We also found that when only a single TM atom is embedded on macropore of TC monolayer, it lead to the formation of four TM-C bonds, and breaks the C–C bonds, distorting the TC monolayer structure (Fig. S2 a and b). Meanwhile, the atomic radius and electronegative of the B and N atoms are similar to those of the C atoms, resulting insignificant changes in the structure after B/N doping. We can see from Fig. 1(c), when TM atoms are embedded in, the equilateral triangle structure is reconstructed and TC monolayer is distorted. Therefore, to maintain the advantages of SACs while avoiding the distortion, we focus on the TM embedded in carbon skeleton of TC monolayer (TM-TC) to modulate the catalytic activity. Then, a TM atom is embedded in the TC monolayer to replace the three C atoms of the equilateral triangle (marked as TM3), which is a suitable embedded method to make the TC monolayer slightly distortion (see Fig. 1d). Ulteriorly, the transition metal synergistic with nonmetal-doped embedded in T-carbon were constructed, and found that the long bond length between nonmetal and TM atoms leads to the TM@X-TC monolayer distorted (see Fig. 1e), and B and N atoms are more suitable to form active center in TM3@X-TC monolayer (see Fig. 1f). Compared with the lattice parameters and carbon ring diameter of the original TC monolayer, TM3@X-TC is the least deformed structure (see Table S1). Therefore, we investigated the multifunctional catalytic properties of TM3@X-TC monolayer by different modulation methods. To study the stability of the material, the thermodynamic, electrochemical and kinetic stability of the TM3@X-TC monolayer were calculated for different modulation methods. The calculation results of formation energy are shown in Fig. 2(a), the more negative formation energy indicates the better thermodynamic stability of the material. We can see that the energies of TM3 types are significantly lower than that of the TM types, indicating that the TC monolayer is more suitable for the simultaneous substitution of the three C atoms, and that the integrity of the macropore can be maintained. Furthermore, we revealed that the formation energy of the TM@X-TC monolayers are significantly lower than those of the single TM embedded in, which indicates that the direct chemical bonding between the TM and C substrate is affected by the lengthy metal–carbon bond, and X atoms make TM atoms easier embedded in TC monolayer. Due to the more positive dissolution potential indicates the better electrochemical stability of the material, we calculated the dissolution potential of TC monolayer under different modulation methods, and the results are shown in Fig. 2(b). We found that only a small part of the TM and TM@B structures show low stability and the rest of the materials has favorable electrochemical stability. In particular, all TM3@X structures have excellent electrochemical stability under acidic conditions. Finally, we calculated the molecular dynamics of TM3@N (TM = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) to describe its dynamic stability, and the results are shown in Fig. 2(c) and Fig. S3. Summarizing, the TM synergistic nonmetal embedded in TC monolayer can efficiently improve the stability of the material, making it one of the best choices for carbon-based catalysts. This conclusion is consistent with graphene and verifies that TC is also expected to be modified by the active center to improve the catalytic performance. 3.2 HER catalytic activity of TC The computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model is successful in predicting the activity and intermediates of various electrochemical reactions, which can reasonably approximate the catalytic reactions of complex systems. Therefore, based on CHE model and the Gibbs free energy (ΔG H*), which is the best descriptor for the HER, we screen reasonable electrocatalysts from the thermodynamic scale. According to Sabatier principle, too negative or too positive values result in strong or weak interactions between the intermediate and the catalyst, and the ΔG H* value close to zero is an excellent HER electrocatalyst. The ΔG H* value of pristine TC monolayer material is 0.50 eV, which means that hydrogen is difficult to decompose from water and adsorb on the surface of the catalyst. It is similar with the results of graphene (1.89 eV [72]), graphyne (0.76 eV [36]) and BPN (0.46 eV [73]), which verifies that the pristine carbon-based materials is inert for the HER. We measured the ΔG H* at the TM atom top sites of TC monolayer under different modulation methods, the results are shown in Fig. 3 (a), and the calculation results of catalytic performance of nonmetal X doped TC monolayer are shown in Fig. 3(b). Obviously, we found that the N site of N-doped TC monolayer has a weak adsorption capacity for hydrogen, while the ΔG H* values of C sites adjacent with N site are more negative than the N site, showing strong adsorption capacity of hydrogen, the results are similar with the pyridine N-doped graphene, where the active center is not the N site, but the adjacent atoms. In contrast, we tested the catalytic performance of the C site in a single TM embedded TC monolayer and found no such results. Then, the Bader charge analysis is calculated to explain the results above, the C atoms obtained electrons mean negative ΔG H* values, showing the stronger adsorption capacity for H protons, the calculation results are shown in Table S2. Furthermore, we compared the results of ΔG H* for TM-TC and TM@X-TC monolayer, and the results are shown in Fig. 3(a). The Gibbs free energy color of the transition metal-loaded TC monolayer is dark green, which means that its HER activity is weak. The color of TM3@X-TC monolayer is increased to light green, especially the structure of N atom as ligand. As mentioned above, our results revealed that the TM@N-TC monolayer can significantly improve the activity of HER. It is uncomprehensive to evaluate the HER performance only by thermodynamics, so we calculated the reaction rate. According to previous studies, the HER reaction rate can be described by exchange current density (i 0) [67], the calculation results of the volcano curve of exchange current density of TM@X-TC monolayer are shown in Fig. 3(d). We can see that the catalytic activity of the structure with nonmetal as ligand is mostly concentrated at the top of the volcano, which is better than a single TM embedding. The top position of the volcano implies a large i 0, which means that the overpotential required to reach a certain total current density is small. Our result showed that TM3@N-TC monolayers have excellent rate, especially the Fe3@N-TC monolayer, even Close to Pt [111]. In addition, we calculated the kinetic potential barrier of the reaction using the charge-extrapolation method, and added two layers of water molecules to approximate the effects of solvation effect and hydrogen bond [74,75], and the details are shown in Figs. S4, S11 and Table S4. The energy barrier of the Heyrovsky mechanism is lower than that of the second Volmer mechanism at 0 V vs. RHE, as shown in the Fig. 4 . The slope of the electrochemical barrier change of the Heyrovsky mechanism is larger than that of the second Volmer mechanism (Fig. S5), so the kinetic barrier of the Heyrovsky mechanism decreases faster as the voltage increases. Therefore, the H* of Co3@N-TC structure tends to combine with H+ to generate hydrogen, rather than adsorb another hydrogen and produce hydrogen. Thus, our results clearly suggest that the TM synergistic nonmetal embedded in TC monolayer can significantly promote the HER catalytic performance, and the Co3@N-TC monolayer has outstanding catalytic potential on both thermodynamic and kinetic scales. 3.3 Catalytical activity for the oxygen reactions Then we focus on the ORR catalytic activity of TC monolayer with different modulation. According to the CHE model [76], the ORR and OER mechanisms are divided into 4 electrons electrochemical steps in acidic conditions, as shown in equations (1)–(4) and Fig. 6 (a). The interaction of each reduction intermediate OOH*, O*, OH* with the catalyst surface determines the reaction free energy of each elementary step in ORR. For the ideal ORR electrocatalyst, the difference between the free energy of the two intermediates is 1.23 eV, and the overpotential close to zero (η = 0). In practice, the difference between the free energy of two adjacent intermediates is difficult to be equal, so the largest step deviating from the equilibrium potential is defined as the potential-determining step (PDS), which is widely used to evaluate the ORR catalytic activity. As mentioned above, the effects of different modulation methods on the ORR/OER performance of TC monolayer were studied. Firstly, we explored the potential impact of macropore on the electrocatalytic performance of TC monolayer. Many carbon-based materials are extensively used as ORR electrocatalyst substrate due to their large macropore and high surface area ratio, such as the derivatives of graphene, the graphyne and OMC. The TC monolayer with a natural macropore diameter of 5.36 Å may cause intriguing interactions between intermediates and products. The adsorption energy (ΔE) of different concentrations is defined by equations (18), and the adsorption energies of intermediates adsorbed around the macropore at different concentrations were calculated, the results are shown in Fig. 5 (a). With the increase of adsorption concentration, the adsorption energies of O*, OOH* and OH* on TC monolayer didn’t change significantly, which verified the excellent capacity of mesopores for intermediates. Interestingly, the ΔE suddenly becomes negative when two oxygen molecules are simultaneously adsorbed, and closer to zero when three oxygen molecules are adsorbed. However, O* is easily adsorbed at the C–C bridge site and is linked by two C–O bonds, so the ΔE is more negative at different concentrations, specifically showing strong adsorption of O*. We revealed that the hydrogen and oxygen atoms between different OOH* form hydrogen bonds in the macropore, which enhance the adsorption capacity of the TC monolayer for OOH* at elevated adsorption concentrations. Moreover, the ΔE of different products at C sites around the macropore are calculated. It can be seen from Fig. 5(b) that the TC monolayer exhibits excellent adsorption capacity for H2 and H2O compared to O2, and the macropore of TC monolayer shows the excellent potential for the products when the adsorption concentration is 3. H2O can also be adsorbed onto the mesopores of TC monolayer by the interacting with hydrogen bonds. Therefore, the macropore composed of 12 carbon atoms can adsorb or accommodate more intermediates and products through low C atom density compared with carbon-based materials, and may exhibit excellent HER/ORR/OER catalytic performance at adsorption concentration of 3. Moreover, to further study the redox reaction catalytic activity of TC monolayers under different modulation methods, the free energy and ORR/OER overpotential were calculated, as shown in Figs. S7–S9. We found that the ΔG 2 step has a negative energy barrier in TM-TC and TM3-TC monolayer, which means that OOH* is hard activated to O*, resulting in ΔG 2 as the PDS of OER and determining the overpotential. Similarly, the ΔG 4 step has a positive energy barrier, meaning that the hydroxyl group is difficult to be hydrogenated to form water, causing the ΔG 4 to determine the ORR overpotential. The TM@X-TC and TM3@X-TC after modification, the reaction energy barriers of ΔG 2 and ΔG 4 steps are all reduced obviously. In particular, the N atom as ligand can significantly reduce the reaction energy barriers of ΔG 1 and ΔG 4 steps. In addition, we found that Co3@N and Ni3@N have extremely low η ORR and η OER, as shown in Fig. 6 (b and c). The adsorption of the intermediates on the catalyst surface is not strong or weak at U = 1.23 V, and the PDS of ORR/OER is low, implying that the reaction could occur at low applied voltage. Our results clearly indicate the potential value of Co3@N-TC and Ni3@N-TC monolayers in OER/ORR bifunctional electrocatalysts. According to the previous research [64], all intermediates of TM-TC monolayer are adsorbed onto the catalyst surface by TM-O bonds, so the adsorption energies of different intermediates are highly linearly dependent. The adsorption energies of ΔG OOH* and ΔG O* for TC monolayer under different modulation methods are plotted as a function of ΔG OH*, and the correlation function could be expressed as (23) Δ G OOH ∗ = 0.99 Δ G OH ∗ + 0.75 eV (24) Δ G O ∗ = 1.13 Δ G OH ∗ + 0.22 eV It can be seen from Fig. 6(d) that the determination coefficients (R 2) of the linear relationship between ΔG OH* vs. ΔG OOH* and ΔG OH* vs. ΔG O* are 0.98 and 0.91 (closer to 1 indicates the stronger correlation), so the free energy of OH* is highly linearly correlated with OOH* and O*, respectively. The ΔG OH* for TM-TC monolayer is highly correlated with other intermediates, this is similar to those of the removal of OH* step is the PDS of carbon-based catalysts [35]. Therefore, the ΔG OH* is expected to describe η ORR and η OER, which is consistent with the Sabatier principle, as shown in Fig. 6(e) and Fig. S4, we can see that the ΔG OH* and η ORR show a perfect volcanic relationship. The left side of the volcano (ΔG OH*< –0.47 eV) indicates a strong bond between OH* and the catalyst surface, resulting in ΔG 4 as the PDS. On the contrary, the right side of the volcano (ΔG OH*> −0.47 eV) indicates slight bonding, resulting in ΔG 1 determining the PDS of ORR. Obviously, the Co3@N and Ni3@N are located at the top of the volcano and exhibit excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. In summary, the Gibbs free energy of OH* has linear relationship with other intermediates and could be used as descriptor to describe the overpotential of ORR/OER. Because of the excellent bifunctional catalytic activity, the kinetic energy barrier of Co3@N-TC monolayer is calculated to describe its ORR/OER electrocatalytic potential. From Fig. 7 (a and b), it can be seen that the maximum kinetic energy barriers of ORR and OER of Co3@N-TC are −0.92 eV and 1.82 eV, respectively, which corresponds to the thermodynamic maximum free energy barrier. Our results verify that the Co3@N-TC monolayer exhibits excellent ORR/OER bifunctional catalytic potential in both kinetics and thermodynamics. Furthermore, the overpotential diagram of HER/ORR/OER was plotted, as shown in Fig. 7(c). The B, N, Cu, Co@B, Fe@N and Zn@N embedded TC monolayer all have excellent HER electrocatalytic performance, the Ni3, Ni@N, Cu@N, Co3@B and Fe3@N embedded TC monolayer have lower OER overpotential than IrO2 (0.56 V) and excellent HER catalytic performance, which have the potential as HER/OER bifunctional electrocatalysts. Especially, the overpotential of Co3@N-TC monolayer (0.83 V) is less than 1, and the HER overpotential is also located in the Gibbs free energy window, which has the excellent potential as HER/ORR/OER multifunctional electrocatalysts. 3.4 Origin for the oxygen reactions It is accepted that the changes in the electronic structure of materials lead to the difference of electrocatalytic activity. To further explore the effect of nonmetal as ligand on electrocatalytic performance, we calculated the energy band, density of states and differential charge density of the TM3@X-TC monolayer, as shown in Figs. S12–S15. We found that all structures have metal properties with non-band gap, which means that the charge is more easily transferred on the surface, and it has potential applications in the field of electrocatalysis. Moreover, the B and TM atoms have significant orbital hybridization near the Fermi level, resulting in smaller characteristic peak. While the N and C atoms have orbital hybridization below the Fermi level, and the d-orbital center (ε d ) of the metal is far away from the Fermi level with the increase of the radius of embedded TM atom. It makes the electrons easier to fill into bonding states, making bond order and covalent bond strength larger. Further, the linear relationship between the ε d and the free energy of the intermediate state is calculated, as shown in Fig. S16. The results verify that the ε d is an excellent descriptor describing the adsorption performance of the ORR/OER intermediate state. As mentioned above, the N atom is an excellent ligand that can cooperate with TM atoms to improve the electronic properties of TC materials and enhance their thermal stability and electrochemical stability. The interaction between the catalyst and the intermediate (OOH*, O*, OH*) determines its adsorption strength. The differential charge density of Co3@N is shown in Fig. 8 (a), we found that all the intermediates are chemically adsorbed onto the TM atom through the TM-O bond, and significant charge transfer occurs between Co3@N and intermediates. To further reveal the origin of N atom as ligand and cooperate with transition metal atoms to improve the catalytic performance, we calculated the COHP with different structures to analyze their bonding strength. The ICOHP values of different intermediates adsorbed on TM3@X-TC monolayer are calculated, the results are shown in Fig. 8(b), the more negative value of ICOHP indicating the stronger bond energy. We found that the ICOHP value of the intermediate O* is more negative, while the values of OH* and OOH* are more positive, indicating that the adsorption of O* on the catalyst surface is stronger. Because of similar bond energy, the results also explain the reason of the high linear correlation between the free energy of OH * and OOH *. Therefore, the OER needs more energy to desorb O*, the PDS is usually ΔG 2 step. On the contrary, the ORR needs more energy to adsorb OH* and OOH*, so the PDS is usually ΔG 4 and ΔG 1 steps and are evenly distributed on the both sides of the volcanic curve. Finally, we also found that the adsorption energies (ΔG abs) of different intermediate are linearly correlated with the ICOHP, and the values of O* (−5.1–−4.72 eV), OH* (−2.71–−2.21 eV), OOH* (−3.21–−2.65 eV) correspond to excellent free energy values (−0.5–0.5 eV), as shown in Fig. 8(e). The R 2 of the linear relationship between ICOHP and ΔG abs are 0.76, 0.82 and 0.91, respectively. In conclusion, the value of ICOHP can explain the PDS in the ORR/OER reaction and can be used as an essential descriptor to describe the adsorption energy. As mentioned above, the free energy of OH* adsorption is proved to be a descriptor that can accurately predict the ORR catalytic activity. To further reveal the origin of adsorption strength, we calculated the projected density of states of OH* adsorbed onto the Co3@N-TC and Co3@B-TC monolayer, the COHP between the Co and O atoms, the results are shown in Fig. 8(c and f). The value of COHP is used to describe the bond energy intensity, the higher peak indicating the greater bond energy between the Co and O atoms. Obviously, the p orbital of the O atom and the d z2, d yz orbital of the Co atom contribute to the bonding state at less than −2 eV, and the other orbitals contribute to the antibonding state at more than −2 eV, as shown in Fig. S15. The interaction of Co3@B and Co3@N is similar, but the p z orbital of O and d xz orbital of Co have a significant characteristic peak at −6 eV, which makes B as a ligand show stronger bonding ability than N, so that the adsorption capacity of Co3@B for OH is greater than that of Co3@N. Moreover, it can be seen from the black dotted rectangle in Fig. 8(d) that the d orbital of the Co atom is hybridized with the p orbital of the hydroxyl group with similar energy levels. Most of the d orbital of the original Co occupy the antibonding state, and the adsorption of OH causes the d orbital of the Co atom to move down and occupy the bonding state. Then, the part of the molecular orbitals (MOs) of Co3@N-TC monolayer interacting with OH at different energy levels are displayed, as shown in Fig. 8(g). A lone electron of the p orbital of the outer hydroxyl group and three lone electrons of the d orbital of Co3@N are perfectly matched into two pairs of electron pairs. Then, the π and π* orbitals near the Fermi level are occupied, so that the hydroxyl group can be appropriately adsorbed onto Co3@N. In conclusion, the interaction between the d orbital of Co and the p orbital of OH leads the electrons to pair up and occupy the downward bonding state, allowing *OH to be appropriately adsorbed onto the Co3@N-TC monolayer, and promote the catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions We theoretically designed a novel macropore TC monolayer, and investigated the synergistic modification of transition metal (TM = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) and nonmetal (X = B, N) atoms to enhance the multifunctional electrocatalytic performance. Our results showed that the TM embedded in nonmetal doped TC (TM@X) can enhance the multifunctional electrocatalytic performance, especially the Co3@N-TC monolayer exhibits superior performance for HER/ORR/OER on both thermodynamic and kinetic scales, and with excellent thermal and electrochemical stability. Furthermore, nonmetal atom as ligand has excellent free energy and large exchange current density. In particular, the N atom as ligand could reduce the energy barrier of the potential-determining step in the redox reaction, making the intermediate appropriately adsorbed onto the TC substrate. Remarkably, the macropore of TC monolayer exhibit excellent adsorption capacity for the intermediates and products of the redox reactions. And we further demonstrate that COHP can well describe the interaction between intermediates and catalysts, the d orbital of Co3@N is significantly hybridized with the p orbital of the intermediates, so that the lone electrons initially occupied in the anti-bonding state pair up and occupy the downward bonding state, allowing *OH to be appropriately adsorbed onto the Co3@N-TC monolayer, and promote the catalytic performance. In addition, the Co-NX-C structure dispersed in the graphene structure shows excellent OER/ORR bifunctional electrocatalytic performance [77], and the structure of Co@N embedded in graphene has outstanding HER/OER/ORR trifunctional electrocatalytic performance [36]. These structures and conclusions indicating the potential of Co atom cooperating with N atom embedding into carbon allotrope in the field of multifunctional electrocatalysis. In conclusion, it is expected that our strategy for designing a synergistic trifunctional electrocatalyst for HER/OER/ORR may be applicable to other carbon-based nano-materials. coredata.dc:description: The design of efficient and low-cost multifunctional electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is critical for the development of clean energy. Two-dimensional (2D) carbon-based nano-materials are becoming more and more popular in heterogeneous catalysis due to their cost-effective and multi-scale tunability as single-atom catalysis (SACs) substrates. In this paper, by using first-principles calculation, we designed and demonstrated a novel macropore T-carbon [110] (TC) monolayer as 2D electrocatalyst substrate for HER/OER/ORR, and the synergistic modification of the transition metal and nonmetal atoms (TM-X) were investigated to enhance the multifunctional electrocatalytic performance. We screened out the Co embedded in N-doped TC (Co3@N-TC) from 30 TM@X-TC monolayers as a trifunctional electrocatalysts, which exhibits superior performance for HER/ORR/OER on both thermodynamic and kinetic scales, and with excellent thermal and electrochemical stability. Then, the TC monolayer is naturally macropore with a diameter of 5.36 Å and exhibits excellent adsorption capacity for the intermediates and products of the redox reactions. Moreover, we revealed the origin of the electrocatalytic activity using the crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) and the molecular orbitals (MOs). The d orbital of Co3@N-TC is significantly hybridized with the p orbital of the intermediates, so that the lone electrons initially occupied in the antibonding state pair up and occupy the downward bonding state, allowing *OH to be appropriately adsorbed onto the TC monolayer. This work not only demonstrates that the TM@X-TC monolayer is a superior synergistic trifunctional electrocatalyst, but also reveals a macropore monolayer material with potential applications in electrocatalysis.
